text: RT @TheLastWord TONIGHT: U.S. Senator Jon @ossoff joins @Lawrence on the #LastWord. Tune in! http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwtIeukWYAUGw44.jpg

RT @ossoff Don’t miss it — @SenatorWarnock will give his maiden speech on the floor of the U.S. Senate at 12:45.

The subject: Voting Rights

I will post the stream as soon as it’s live.
Statement by Sen. Jon @Ossoff on Georgia shootings: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwsXlE2WEAEf9Ym.jpg

Tonight, I’m joining @maddow a little after 9:15 PM ET to discuss the anti-democratic efforts in GA—and across the nation—to suppress the vote. I made clear on the Senate floor today Congress must take action to protect voting rights. Tune in!

We owe it to our civil rights heroes, like the late Congressman John Lewis, to ensure all voices can be heard at the ballot box. By passing key voting rights legislation, such as the For the People Act, we can #ProtectTheVote for generations to come. #TheVoteIsSacred http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwuF1fBWQAMc_rQ.jpg

RT @RonWyden Glad to have @SenatorWarnock in the Senate to continue the fight to protect voting rights as Republicans nationwide chip away at a Americans’ constitutional right to vote. #ProtectTheVote https://twitter.com/SenatorWarnock/status/1372230275330101251 QT @SenatorWarnock As efforts to rollback critical voting rights and protections are growing in Georgia—and nationwide—I’m speaking on the actions we can take in Congress to protect the foundation of our democracy & ensure every single voice is heard. #TheVoteIsSacred https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1vAxRwMePmNKl

RT @SenCortezMasto A timely maiden speech from my colleague @SenatorWarnock! 
 
He’s worked tirelessly in the fight to protect voting rights and has hit the ground running in Congress. The Senate is stronger because of his work to #ProtectTheVote. https://twitter.com/SenatorWarnock/status/1372230275330101251 QT @SenatorWarnock As efforts to rollback critical voting rights and protections are growing in Georgia—and nationwide—I’m speaking on the actions we can take in Congress to protect the foundation of our democracy & ensure every single voice is heard. #TheVoteIsSacred https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1vAxRwMePmNKl

Today, in light of last night's horrific events, I am reminded of Dr. King’s message of driving out darkness with light; hate with love. I stand with the families grieving the loss of a loved one & with Atlanta’s AAPI community. We will work through this tragedy together.

RT @SenatorBaldwin I support the #ForThePeople Act because I support more people voting, not less. Let’s break down barriers to ensure everyone can access the right to vote. #VotingRightsAct #VRAA http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwsV89kWUAMZf-0.jpg

RT @GaryPeters It’s an honor to call Reverend @SenatorWarnock a colleague and friend. His election in Georgia was an inspiration to folks across the country & I’m excited to work with him to expand voting rights and deliver results for Americans—no matter who you are or where you live. https://twitter.com/ReverendWarnock/status/1372219009253408768 QT @ReverendWarnock Today I’m giving my first speech on the floor of the United States Senate because in Georgia and across the country we’re seeing voter suppression that threatens our democracy. 

Your vote is sacred, and I won’t stop fighting to protect it.

RT @SenJackyRosen It's a privilege to watch my friend @SenatorWarnock give his maiden Senate floor speech on our sacred right to vote. 

Voting rights are under attack, and I'm ready to work with Senator Warnock and all my colleagues to #ProtectTheVote.

RT @PattyMurray Our right to vote is one of the most powerful tools we have to enact change in our country. Glad to have you in the Senate to #ProtectTheVote and ensure all voices can be heard at the ballot box, @SenatorWarnock. https://twitter.com/SenatorWarnock/status/1372230275330101251 QT @SenatorWarnock As efforts to rollback critical voting rights and protections are growing in Georgia—and nationwide—I’m speaking on the actions we can take in Congress to protect the foundation of our democracy & ensure every single voice is heard. #TheVoteIsSacred https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1vAxRwMePmNKl

As efforts to rollback critical voting rights and protections are growing in Georgia—and nationwide—I’m speaking on the actions we can take in Congress to protect the foundation of our democracy & ensure every single voice is heard. #TheVoteIsSacred https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1vAxRwMePmNKl

RT @SenAlexPadilla Let’s call polices like ending no excuse absentee voting & limiting weekend voting what they are: voter suppression. We must fight these injustices & pass the John Lewis #VotingRightsAct to expand access to the ballot box & #ProtectTheVote.

I’m headed to the floor of the United States Senate now to give my first speech—defending our sacred right as Americans to the ballot box. I hope you’ll join me by tuning in via livestream here on Twitter or on Facebook. #TheVoteIsSacred https://twitter.com/SenatorWarnock/status/1371885169355919361 QT @SenatorWarnock On Wednesday, March 17, at 12:45pm ET, I’ll take the floor of the Senate to defend the very foundation of our democracy –– the sacred right to vote.

I promise you, Georgia, I will never stop fighting to protect & expand access to the ballot box. #TheVoteIsSacred http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwnpzTdWYAECWJN.jpg

RT @gillibrandny Your vote is your voice — and we cannot allow anyone to take that away. It's time to end racist voter suppression, protect voting rights, and make it easy and simple to register and cast your vote. #YourVoteYourVoice http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwsXXZKWEAIh3Ae.jpg

RT @SenatorHassan The right to vote is the foundation of our democracy. It's how we speak up for what we believe in. But too many Americans still face barriers when trying to cast their vote. That's why we must pass the John Lewis #VotingRightsAct.

RT @RepBourdeaux Our democracy works best when all our voices can be heard. It is time for the Senate to take action & pass critical legislation such as the John Lewis #VotingRightsAct & the #ForThePeople Act. We can’t delay a moment longer. #YourVoteYourVoice http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwsWP4HWQAIAbsD.jpg

As I prepare to give my first speech on the Senate floor, I'm reminded I stand here on the shoulders of civil rights heroes like John Lewis. As Georgia's first African American Senator, I'm committed to protecting our sacred right to vote. We will not go back—not now, not ever. https://twitter.com/ajconwashington/status/1372155332072505350 QT @ajconwashington Excerpts of his prepared remarks indicate that Warnock will strongly condemn efforts in Georgia & other states to restrict voting access.  https://www.ajc.com/politics/warnock-in-first-floor-speech-will-blast-proposed-voting-restrictions-in-georgia/XYKJV5P6VFEFHC6XKAF6E5GRX4/

My amendment allows certain grants in this bill to be used to create databases detailing where sane nurses are located.

My 2nd amendment is a direct response to an issue in my home state of North Carolina. Unfortunately, sexual assault nurse examiners (SANE) nurses can be difficult to locate. Some survivors travel to multiple hospitals to find care.

I’m also proud two of my amendments are included. My first amendment aims to protect the safety and privacy of survivors by creating a statutory mandate that a victim’s safety should be central to housing decisions made by covered housing providers.

1 in 4 women experience severe physical abuse from an intimate partner in their lifetime.

I’m joining @Maddow tonight to talk about my speech on the floor of the United States Senate today in defense of voting rights. Tune in!

It’s essential to our democracy that we pass the For The People Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act. 

No Senate rule should override the integrity of our democracy itself.

The last time the Voting Rights Act was reauthorized, George W. Bush was president and it passed the Senate 98-0. Now it can’t even get a vote. 

We have our differences, but there should be 100 votes to make it easier for Americans to make their voices heard in our democracy.

The For The People Act will make it easier for all eligible Americans to vote by: 

🗳️Establishing automatic voter registration
📅Requiring at least 2 weeks of early voting, including weekend hours 
📬Prohibiting restrictions to vote by mail
❌Preventing voter roll purges

We are witnessing right now a massive and unabashed assault on voting rights and voter access unlike anything we have seen since the Jim Crow era.

Twice as many Georgians voted in the January runoffs than ever before and they sent the state’s first Black senator and first Jewish senator to Washington. 

But some politicians didn't approve, and instead of changing their message, they're trying to change the rules.

Today I’m giving my first speech on the floor of the United States Senate because in Georgia and across the country we’re seeing voter suppression that threatens our democracy. 

Your vote is sacred, and I won’t stop fighting to protect it.

I want to thank the constituent who shared her story with me and every person out there who is speaking out about how we can better take care of survivors. Your bravery is why we’re here passing this bill today, and I’m just honored to be a part of it. 8//

My amdt will allow Violence Against Women Act funding to be used to implement vertical prosecution systems. I want every survivor’s case to get the attention and care it deserves and, most importantly, I want every survivor to feel like they are truly heard and represented. 7/

As you can imagine, one of the big reasons vertical prosecution doesn’t happen as much as it should is the cost. District attorneys’ offices do not always have the resources to hire more attorneys to handle cases. 6/

According to the National Sexual Violence Resource Center, ‘vertical prosecution has shown to improve conviction rates, reduce victim trauma, and provide more consistent, appropriate sentencing.’ 5/

https://www.nsvrc.org/sites/default/files/publications/2018-09/Best%20Practices%20for%20Prosecution.pdf

She asked that I encourage what’s called ‘vertical prosecution,’ a plan for prosecuting cases in which one prosecuting attorney remains the primary individual responsible for the case, as well as the primary contact for victim witnesses from complaint through sentencing. 4/

This is a process that’s harrowing enough on its own. To have to relive what happened over and over in order to get a new attorney up to speed—to not feel like you have a relationship with that person—it’s just unthinkable to me. 3/
She shared that, over the course of her legal proceedings, she’d had five different prosecutors on her case. And, not surprisingly, she felt like none of them were really representing her. 2/

I’m feeling especially emotional about the vote on the Violence Against Women Act reauthorization today because I was able to get an amendment included in this bill that was inspired by a conversation I had with a constituent last year. 

She had survived a sexual assault. 

1/

We appreciate the opportunity to share ideas on how we pass the boldest legislation through Congress so every American has the opportunity to thrive—not just survive.
 
We look forward to regular collaboration and to continuing these conversations at a second meeting this week.

This includes making the Child Tax Credit expansion permanent, making the tax code more fair, ensuring the wealthy pay their share, and addressing the massive and unprecedented income inequality in this country.
 
We also shared our views on the need to eliminate the filibuster.

Members of the @USProgressives had a productive meeting at the White House today.
 
We strategized on the path forward for a $15 minimum wage and discussed a bold, transformative Build Back Better package as well as additional economic and racial justice priorities.

Let’s put people over profits.

It is long past due for the millions of American citizens living in Puerto Rico to get the representation that they deserve.
My home state of New Mexico had a similar struggle to achieve statehood. It took 50 New Mexico statehood bills and 64 years before we were finally admitted to the United States.

The Puerto Rico Admission Act will create a clear and direct path to formally admit Puerto Rico as a state and will constitute Congress’s response to citizens in Puerto Rico and provide a formal offer of statehood.
That’s why I’m proud to join @RepJenniffer and  @RepDarrenSoto and our bicameral coalition of @SenBrianSchatz, @RonWyden, and @SenAlexPadilla to introduce the Puerto Rico Admission Act in the Senate.

Last November, a majority of Puerto Ricans voted in favor of statehood and for full voting representation in the United States. Congress now has a moral responsibility to respond.

By passing #HJRes17 today, the House voted to remove the arbitrary time limit for states to ratify the #EqualRightsAmendment, bringing our nation one step closer to affirming women’s equality in our Constitution. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwszTlmW8AcalHE.jpg

Michigan ratified the #ERA on May 22, 1972.

Recently, Nevada, Illinois and Virginia also ratified the ERA, meaning 38 states have now done so. But Congress must lift the previously set deadline to ratify the ERA for it to become the 28th Amendment to our Constitution.

Ensuring these words, the #EqualRightsAmendment, becomes part of the Constitution is critical.  It would help to combat discrimination women face every day, including when it comes to pay and access to health care.

“Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex.”

These words belong in our founding document—to make discrimination based on sex unconstitutional.

The federal government is working to get direct relief into your hands swiftly and urgently—because working families need relief now. If you haven't already gotten your payment, this tool will help tell you how much you'll receive and when: https://www.irs.gov/coronavirus/get-my-payment

The IRS is working to send as much money electronically as possible to households with direct deposit or bank account information, and if that information isn't provided, the payments will be sent out as paper checks and debit cards.
You don't need to do anything in order to get your direct payments. Eligibility is based on your 2020 tax returns. If you haven’t filed for 2020, it's based on your 2019 return.

We have an opportunity to make equal rights under the law a reality for our mothers, our daughters, our granddaughters, and ourselves. 

#ERANow #EqualFuture

Let’s just imagine if the #ERA has been ratified in the 1970s – as it should have been. Would we have needed today the #MeToo & Time’s Up movements? Would #VAWA and other legislation addressing sexual assault been passed must sooner?

Unfortunately, we’re seeing the effects of gender inequality acutely during this pandemic. An estimated one million more women than men have lost their jobs and a disproportionate number of those suffering are Black women and Latinas.

We may not always be able to control – nor should women’s rights be dependent on – who controls state govts, who’s in the WH, Congress, or on SCOTUS. 
Our rights shouldn’t be determined by these types of things – it should be in the document they interpret -- the Constitution.

There is no time limit on equality. The Equal Rights Amendment passed the 38 states needed, including my great state of New York. 

It’s long past time for women to be in the Constitution.

Today, I went to the House floor to urge all of my colleagues to vote to remove the arbitrary deadline on the #ERA

We just passed it!

#NoDeadlineOnEquality 🧵 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ews1gUKXEAMuwKl.jpg

By passing the #ForthePeople Act, we can take a historic step toward getting the money out of politics and bringing the American people back in.

✔️Ban partisan gerrymandering;
✔️Close lobbyist loopholes; and
✔️Make voting easier for college students.

It also draws on our leadership in Colorado to expand automatic voter registration and mail-in voting.

Our democracy is at risk – from voter suppression, dark money, foreign interference, and more. Like generations before us, we have a duty to strengthen our democracy. 
 
We can do that with the #ForThePeople Act, the most consequential reform proposal in a generation. THREAD⬇️

We in Congress/WhiteHouse/DOJ/Governors/Mayors have our work cut out for us. Let us pass NoHateAct, followup ExecMemo with more resources, and fight this hate with constant/relentless engagement. No single law can solve these problems, but that shouldn’t stop us from trying (END)

We need cities/states/federal to listen. Really listen. Work with the communities to identify needs. Again not just AAPI communities. Minority/immigrant and other vulnerable and underrepresented communities all need to be at the table. 12/13

I’ve received a lot of messages overnight. Many have asked what can you do to help. Please spread the word. I spoke to someone yesterday that told me that they didn’t realize the struggles of AAPI until they heard Biden mention it. We have more work to do to raise awareness.11/13

It’s also worth noting that all but one of the victims yesterday were women. The Senate let the #ViolenceAgainstWomenAct expire. Today, I’m going to vote again to bring it back so we can add tools to addressing violence targeting women. 10/13

Systemic racism is deep and we must always recognize the struggles of others. We mourn collectively the anniversary of Breonna Taylor’s murder this past week. Let us all commit to be vigilant and present in each other’s struggles. 9/13 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwrjjTAWEAAar5S.jpg

We should never be outraged by violence only targeting those who look like us. Hate comes in many forms. I will work to be a better ally and an empathetic person to understand all these manifestations and to fight for others as I would for my own children. 8/13

I’m very aware that I am AAPI member of Congress representing a district that 85% white and less than 3% AAPI. I’ve had people recommend that I not talk about my heritage/AAPI issues here. But I have to say that people in my district want me to stand up to hate in all forms. 7/13

Between COVID/gun violence/healthcare/overdose/hatred/racism and other causes, we have grown accustomed to so much death in our communities. My 5 yr old boy talks about people we lost in last year with too much normalcy. We should fight for every life. 6/13

It’s too early to tell if these specific measures would have prevented this particular tragedy, but what is important is that we not be numb/apathetic in the face of violence. We have to keep working to reduce. Otherwise we implicitly accept violence as normal. 5/13

What we saw last night also reinforced the deep problem we have of gun violence. Last week I voted in Congress to pass universal background checks for gun safety. #HR8 is a right step for our nation. Nearly every American supports it. It is wrong that we fall short. 4/13 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewri8CFXMAQU6Bs.jpg

I can’t tell you how much it means to me and others that anti-AAPI violence has gotten attention. Biden’s mention in his speech was powerful. Now we need follow through. Give AAPI communities more resources/coordination. Give us tools to counter. Listen to our needs. 3/13 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ewrix7kXIAYYaIz.jpg

I’ve been asked if the violence against AAPI is new, and if it is getting better with the increased recent visibility. The answer to both is no. Discrimination/violence existed before COVID and it will continue after. And sadly, I don’t think we have seen the worst of it. 2/13

There was a mass shooting in America last night. Sadly that is not uncommon. Many of the victims were AAPI. Tragedy sits at the intersection of multiple broken parts of our society. To honor victims and save lives, we must make progress across all. #StopAsianHate (THREAD) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwriaBaXMAEYNJO.jpg
